Award.AwardTitle: XXXII SCAR and Open Science Conference
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports an international community Open Science Conference (OSC) that will be held in conjunction with the Scientific Committee for Antarctic Research (SCAR) XXXII meeting scheduled for July 13?25, 2012 in Portland, OR. The overarching theme of the OSC is to address the current status and future prospects of the Antarctic and Southern Ocean sciences and help developing scientific capacity in the SCAR member countries, emerging national and international Antarctic programs, students and early career scientists. The United States has as an important role today in setting the agenda and carrying it forward as it has had in past decades. The NSF's Office of Polar Programs, NRC's Polar Research Board, U.S. delegation to SCAR, and individual research scientists all participate in that effort. The SCAR/OSC provides an exceptional platform for information sharing and networking among the diverse and disparate U.S. and international Antarctic science communities. The location of the meeting in North America promises to attract the largest U.S. scientists' participation in the meeting's history.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We organized and hosted the XXXII Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR) and its Open Science Conference (OSC) in 13-25 July, 2012 in Portland, OR. It is important that investments in Antarctic science be well justified and optimize limited resources, and that the community develops and shares a collective vision of future scientific directions. The SCAR OSC has never before been held in the United States and the SCAR Delegates have not met in the U.S. since 1986. We thus had, in hosting the SCAR meetings, a relatively rare opportunity to demonstrate national support for and interest in Antarctic science. 

A total of 930 abstracts were accepted for presentation during the four days of the OSC, of which 470 were given as posters. Participants from 34 countries, totalling 819 people, registered for the SCAR meetings.  A subsidized registration program for students (the first 200 accepted abstracts from students were awarded free" registration; 160 students accepted the award) was useful for advertising and for broadening participation. Subsidized housing at University Place, a university conference center, (100 people at $25 per night) also supported broad participation.

The Local Organizing Committee was composed of eight student interns.  The students come from diverse departments, including business, accounting, communications, geology, biology, and art. Of the eight interns hired thus far, 4 are women and 1 is a Pacific Islander. Each had their own portfolio of responsibility.  We met on a weekly basis in the months leading up to the symposium and on a daily basis the few weeks prior. Our organizational structure was very flat, so every intern’s contribution was central to group success and every intern had an opportunity for leadership. The intern and volunteer programs were structured to promote student access to experiences that support their educational goals. We expect also that these programs will provide students with opportunities to explore novel ideas and career options.

Remaining funds from the conference were used to provide partial travel funding for American students and scientists to attend the 2014 SCAR Open Science Conference that was held in Auckland, NZ.  We funded 35 participants, including, 16 PhD students; 3 MSc students; 1 Undergraduate; 13 Early Career Scientists; and 2 Associate professors 2.
